data.text: Insurance Requires a Bike Lock. What Lock Do You Carry?
Thanks for adding me! I‚Äôve been touring on and off for 30 years. I have a question though What locks are folks carrying, insurance generally demands sold secure gold and they weigh a ton!
I‚Äôm interested in this too. I hate the weight of locks but need something secure but not my Abus D-lock
data.author: Tom Monaghan

data.text: For peace of mind, I'm not too fussed about the extra 1kg
data.author: Stuart Jessey

data.text: I get that but we all try to squeeze the ounces down only to lug a brick afterwards! Obviously campsites don‚Äôt have much in the way of secure anchors either!
data.author: Ian Ward

data.text: Abus bordo lite
data.author: Dahni Beddo

data.text: the bordo isn‚Äôt gold rated so doesn‚Äôt meet the insurance stipulations üò¢
data.author: Ian Ward

data.text: does your insurance cover world wide?
data.author: Dahni Beddo

data.text: I‚Äôm still looking but need to check my household, I‚Äôve a new bike on the way and have been quite relaxed about locks in the past as I‚Äôve not often toured solo(so shop stops etc are easier).
data.author: Ian Ward

data.text: ah yeah new bike deffo wanna take care then
data.author: Dahni Beddo

data.text: been a tourist for over 25 years, never carried anythig other than a light cable lock, but i don't leave my bike in urban areas, unattended for more than nipping into a shop etc, or leave it with museum guards where I do. The only time I've heard of a touring bike go missing was a lad who left it outside a coffes shop in amsterdaam whilst he inbibed and then had to get the train home to germany. Most of my touring is in remote places away from humans !
data.author: Kevin Allerton

data.text: haha I‚Äôll not be doing that then! I‚Äôm the same for years I used an old squire cable(still got it) then had a frame mounted cable alarm(great for tandems). It strikes me that insurers don‚Äôt get what we do! Anyone spending a few grand will have thought about weight. Strong, light, cheap - pick 2!
data.author: Ian Ward

data.text: There is no getting around this. All the gold standards weigh a ton. But that is what you need to be covered. But how do the insurance companies know what you use? Do not be suprised if they refuse to pay out because you cannot prove you bought the required lock.
data.author: Steve Lindley

data.text: or if you can‚Äôt prove the lock was defeated‚Ä¶.
data.author: Ian Ward

data.text: The lock is often left behind. But yes. If the insurance company can wangle out of it they will.
data.author: Steve Lindley

data.text: I have a small cable lock but have recently installed a bike alarm I found on Amazon. It's very easy to install and very loudüôÇ once set it you touch the bike it sends out a warning beep if you try moving it it all hell breaks looseüòÅ I thought it ideal for when you pop into a shop of cafe etc
data.author: Douglas Woodhouse
Douglas Woodhouse

data.text: I have one integrated with a cable lock but can‚Äôt find similar replacement.
data.author: Ian Ward

data.text: that sounds goodüôÇüëç
data.author: Douglas Woodhouse

data.text: it is but they don‚Äôt make them anymore‚Ä¶
data.author: Ian Ward

data.text: I made my own out of 3mm stainless steel wire, with loops pressed to 20 ton. It is 2m long and will go round a post and through my bags, frame and wheels. Its very light and fits in my jersey pocket. But its a cafe stop lock and can easily be cut with Bolt cutter. But I have not lost a bike yet. So it works.
data.author: Steve Lindley

data.text: that‚Äôs the one I have! Brilliant I follow it up, I‚Äôve found this to be rather better than the build quality suggests!
data.author: Ian Ward

data.text: You‚Äôll note it‚Äôs on my picture!
data.author: Ian Ward

data.text: pity‚òπÔ∏è
data.author: Douglas Woodhouse

data.text: posted the exact lock I own! But they only seem to sell direct, I‚Äôll be ordering!
data.author: Ian Ward

data.text: I think it's like all these things it's just a deterrent it's just a case of making it less attractive as a target.
data.author: Douglas Woodhouse

data.text: exactly hence a noisy alarm!
data.author: Ian Ward

data.text: looks good, good cable length too.
data.author: Douglas Woodhouse

data.text: 8 ft does a tandem easy but the thicker 4 ft is an option, not sure it makes much odds as it s the alarm that counts and 8mm is easy cut too. It‚Äôs a neat frame mount and steel banded under the plastic. 9 volts gives a good battery life and it‚Äôs plenty loud!
data.author: Ian Ward

data.text: I watch a video on Tube about bikepacking security but more about protecting the gear in your panniers this lady said she puts all here dirty knickers on the top! and has never had any problems for something like 20years! ü§£ü§£ü§£
data.author: Douglas Woodhouse

data.text: I once had French customs goes through my bag the expression when they found my unwashed kecks !ü§¢. They were very interested in the loose stock cube rattling around the bottom of the pannier too‚Ä¶
data.author: Ian Ward

data.text: Stock cube....yea rightü§£
data.author: Douglas Woodhouse

data.text: I wouldn't touch her bag either of there was twenty years worth of dirty knickers in it üòÑ
data.author: Dougie Owens

data.text: Mine ask for receipt or proof of purchase of lock, that is Bikmo. Others ask for photos of broken lock.
data.author: Joseph Forrest

data.text: With 30 years experience, you have not solved the lock problem
data.author: Mark Connelly

data.text: generally my bike never leaves my sight but occasionally pies and sleep lead to lapses‚Ä¶.
data.author: Ian Ward

data.text: I carry a cable lock. A thief can defeat anything, so it's more of temporary deterrent. I try to keep bike inside a building as much as possible.
data.author: Mark Connelly

data.text: that‚Äôs common sense! And I do the same, but doesn‚Äôt meet the requirements of your insurance which was the question.
data.author: Ian Ward

data.text: save enough money so that if a bike gets stolen, you can buy a new one. Bikes for touring don't need to be expensive.
data.author: Mark Connelly

data.text: the value of my bikes isn‚Äôt the cost!
data.author: Ian Ward

data.text: true, but if stolen even with insurance, it's the same thing.
data.author: Mark Connelly

data.text: I bought two last year‚Ä¶one for rear of bike and one for front‚Ä¶came with carry bag and the larger ones go round your waist or over the shoulder.

Litelok Motorcycle Lock Review | Can We Cut Through It??

data.author: Monty Michael William Wyatt

data.text: Toured Iceland last June. I didn‚Äôt carry a lock at all. Perhaps I should have but no problem at all. Left my bike in the campground for hours. If I‚Äôm in a more dense area I carry a cable lock. No lock will stop someone who really wants your bike. It will slow them down.
data.author: Richard Brass

data.text: I also make a point of chatting to my neighbours on a site, it‚Äôs normally interesting but they then know who the bike belongs too! I bet Iceland was great!
data.author: Ian Ward

data.text: Really good point about talking to others. Iceland is amazing.
data.author: Richard Brass

data.text: besides which it‚Äôs one of the reasons I like cycle touring, you can cover the distance and still have the time and opportunity to make a connection with the place and people.
data.author: Ian Ward

data.text: Agree totally. It slows everything down and allows for a rich experience with the people and geography. I always feel so free when traveling by bicycle. I love the feeling of carrying what I need. The unknown around the corner. The people I will meet. The loneliness of the road. The cold night in my tent. The changing of cloths from rain to sun. The finally hitting the top of a pass. The falling asleep midday on a bench. I could go on and on.
data.author: Richard Brass

data.text: I can do without the cold in a tent but I agree!
data.author: Ian Ward

data.text: I use a cable lock finishing with a motorbike disk lock on the seat tube, so even if they chop the cable they cannot ride it easily as it fouls the pedals. Also a small tracker is hidden. But I've also not left the bike unattended in a big urban centre. TBH our bike insurance doesn't specify they type of lock, just that it must be locked to something secure. Insurance wont be much help mid tour anyway.
data.author: Jon Shaw

data.text: trackers seem a good idea, what brand do you use, I‚Äôll probably get the frame permanently marked too.
data.author: Ian Ward

data.text:
used a couple, just got this one which is less than 5x2x2 cm https://www.amazon.co.uk/Hangang-Anti-loss-Personal-documents-Motorcycle/dp/B07F74KK1K/ref=sr_1_32?crid=3SLUOAYVUWE5G&keywords=gps+tracker&qid=1652038043&s=electronics&sprefix=gps%2Celectronics%2C86&sr=1-32

amazon.co.uk
data.author: Jon Shaw

data.text: that looks good, how does it attach?
data.author: Ian Ward

data.text: it is supposed to be magnetic - magnet with stick pad supplied. I don't think it is up to the job off-road ... trying to figure out! If I didn't have bar end shifters I'd try there! It needs to be removable to charge.
data.author: Jon Shaw

data.text: Squire offer a fantastic choice of sold secure bike locks. The Eiger compact D-Lock is one of the lightest around and is sold secure gold approved. It also comes with a free security cable! https://www.squirelocks.co.uk/shop/eiger-compact.html
data.author: Neil Hudson

data.text: I‚Äôll check it out!
data.author: Ian Ward

data.text: They do look good and as you say not as heavy as some!
data.author: Ian Ward

data.text: I use a good combination lock, never too faraway from my trusty steed, for it to get lifted anyway....
data.author: Larry Gowar

data.text: I don't carry a lock - too much weight for a good one and light ones are pointless. Just keep the bike close all the time or stop places other people are not.
data.author: Mark Vernon

data.text: My basic solution is to carry so much stuff on the bike that nobody in their right mind would want to steal it, much less be able to ride off with it
data.author: Sam Roberson

data.text: A bit extreme! but cant fault your thought patternü§£ü§£
data.author: Douglas Woodhouse

data.text: I favour the Kryptonite cable keyed lock , locking qr skewers ( pinhead or similar ) ... bike mainly at risk overnight and also tend to "tether" it to my tent.
data.author: Paul Gagan
